deliberation: Examined for idiomatic or metaphorical expressions. The clause "the word of YHWH came to me" is the standard prophetic reception formula and uses motion language for an intangible message.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me
ground: arrival from outside, initiating encounter
directedness toward a recipient
communication/contact
posture: emphasizes initiative and reality of revelation
theological assurance of God's active speaking
instances.explanation: The intangible divine message is depicted as a concrete "word" that travels and arrives, personifying and metonymically representing God's act of revelation.

deliberation: Looked for poetic or proverbial imagery. The proverb about fathers eating sour grapes and children's teeth being set on edge is a compact figurative saying that encapsulates an idea about intergenerational guilt.

instances.hebrew_text: אָבוֹת יֹאכְלוּ בֹסֶר וְשִׁנֵּי הַבָּנִים תִּקְהֶינָה
instances.english_text: Parents eat sour grapes and their children’s teeth are blunted
target: the transfer of consequences/guilt between generations
experience of punishment for others' sins
vehicle: eating sour grapes affecting someone else’s teeth
ground: one party's action causing unpleasant consequences for another
involuntary suffering from others' choices
unfair-seeming linkage of cause and effect
instances.explanation: The proverb uses the image of fathers eating unripe grapes and children feeling the dental effect as a metaphor and idiom for children suffering consequences for their parents’ sins.

deliberation: Checked whether the oath formula or mention of the proverb is figurative beyond formulaic usage. "As I live" is a standard divine oath and the rest is literal prohibition of using the proverb.
Considered whether "nephesh" is purely anthropological or a figure. The verse uses "all the nephesh" and "the nephesh that sins" in a way that treats "life/soul" as standing for the whole person.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן כׇּל־הַנְּפָשׁוֹת לִי הֵנָּה ... הַנֶּפֶשׁ הַחֹטֵאת הִיא תָמוּת
instances.english_text: Consider, all lives are Mine ... Only the person (lit. the soul) who sins shall die
ground: the 'soul' represents the whole living person
life as that which belongs to God
seat of identity and accountability
posture: asserts divine ownership over each person
instances.explanation: "Nephesh" (life/soul) functions as a synecdoche for the whole person: the 'soul that sins' means the person who sins, not a detachable part.

deliberation: The verse defines a righteous man and mentions doing justice and righteousness. These terms are moral-legal categories used straightforwardly without evident figurative imagery.
Looked especially at cultic and idiomatic phrases. "Eat on the mountains" and "raise his eyes to the idols" are both stock idioms for idol worship, not merely geographic or optical descriptions.

instances.english_text: he has not eaten on the mountains
vehicle: festive cultic banquets at hilltop shrines
ground: ritual meals as emblematic of worship
high places as locations of forbidden cults
physical participation signifying religious allegiance
posture: marks such participation as disqualifying for righteousness
instances.explanation: The phrase condenses idolatrous worship into the image of eating at shrines on the hills, using location and meal as a metonymic idiom for the whole cultic practice.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעֵינָיו לֹא נָשָׂא אֶל־גִּלּוּלֵי בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: and has not raised his eyes to the fetishes (idols) of the House of Israel
target: inner orientation of worship and trust
vehicle: lifting up the eyes toward idols
ground: directing one’s gaze symbolizes seeking/help or honor
eyes as indicators of desire and worship
orientation toward an object as devotion
instances.explanation: The idiom uses the physical act of lifting up the eyes toward idols as a metonymic and metaphorical way to speak of seeking, honoring, or trusting them.

deliberation: Actions listed (not oppressing, returning pledge, not robbing, giving bread, clothing the naked) are social deeds that can be literally performed. While they can represent charity more broadly, here they seem concrete legal-ethical examples rather than figurative.
Most financial terms are literal. The phrase about withdrawing one’s hand from injustice stands out as bodily-language for ceasing wrongdoing.

instances.english_text: he has abstained from wrongdoing (lit. he has withdrawn his hand from injustice)
target: ceasing active participation in unjust practices
ground: the hand represents active agency
to pull back the hand pictures refraining from action
ending physical contact symbolizes ending involvement
posture: frames injustice as something one should pull back from
instances.explanation: The hand stands metonymically for one’s actions, and withdrawing it from injustice is a metaphorical idiom for stopping unjust behavior.

deliberation: The notable figurative element is the common biblical metaphor of "walking" in statutes, where moral obedience is pictured as travel along a path.

instances.english_text: if he has followed My laws (lit. walked in My statutes)
vehicle: walking within statutes as if they were a path
ground: ongoing, step-by-step progress
staying within set boundaries/directions
life as a path requiring guidance
posture: presents obedience as an ordered, guided life-journey
instances.explanation: Obedience is conceptualized as walking along God’s statutes as though they formed a road, using journey imagery for moral conduct.

deliberation: The description of the son includes moral labels and one idiomatic phrase, "shedder of blood," which stands for a murderer.

instances.english_text: a ruffian, a shedder of blood
ground: blood stands for life
spilling blood signifies taking life
visceral image for violent killing
posture: frames murder in shocking, physical terms
instances.explanation: The idiom "shedder of blood" uses blood metonymically for life, so that "shedding blood" stands for committing murder.

deliberation: Again examined cultic and sexual phrases. As before, "eaten on the mountains" is idiomatic for idol worship; the defilement of a neighbor’s wife is literal sexual transgression.

instances.english_text: That is, he has eaten on the mountains
ground: ritual meals epitomize participation in a cult
high places symbolize idolatrous worship sites
table-fellowship as covenantal association
posture: associates it with the son's wickedness
instances.explanation: As in verse 6, "eating on the mountains" is a metonymic, idiomatic way of referring to participating in idolatrous worship celebrated with meals at high places.

deliberation: Most actions (wronging, robbing, not returning pledge) are straightforward. The repeated idiom of "raising his eyes to the idols" functions as earlier.

instances.english_text: he has raised his eyes to the fetishes (idols)
vehicle: lifting the eyes toward an object
ground: gaze indicates desire, reliance, and honor
turning one's eyes symbolizes turning one's heart
physical looking stands for inner seeking
posture: condemns the inner and outer orientation toward idols
instances.explanation: The idiom uses the act of lifting the eyes toward idols as a metonymic metaphor for turning one's desire and trust toward them.

deliberation: Financial phrases are literal. The closing statement "his blood will be upon him" is an idiom where blood stands for guilt and 'on him' frames responsibility as a burden resting on the person.

instances.english_text: his blood shall be upon him
target: guilt and liability for his own death
vehicle: one’s own blood being upon oneself
blood as something resting on a person
ground: blood symbolizes life taken and consequent guilt
what is 'upon' someone is their burden/charge
self-caused outcomes cling to the doer
posture: stresses self-responsibility for the death sentence
instances.explanation: The idiom uses blood metonymically for guilt, picturing it as resting upon the guilty party as a burden or stain they themselves bear.

deliberation: This verse speaks of a son seeing his father's sins and not doing likewise. "Seeing" functions cognitively but in standard Hebrew this is conventional perception language, not a crafted metaphor.
Parallel to verses 6 and 11, again contains idioms for idolatry. Both "eating on the mountains" and "raising his eyes to the fetishes" recur as figurative descriptions of idol worship.

instances.english_text: He has not eaten upon the mountains
ground: cultic meals epitomize worship practices
high places are emblematic of forbidden shrines
joining a meal signals religious fellowship
posture: frames cultic meals as morally loaded actions
instances.explanation: The phrase condenses the complex practice of idolatrous worship into the physical image of eating at mountain shrines, a metonymic metaphor for the whole cult.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעֵינָיו לֹא נָשָׂא אֶל־גִּלּוּלֵי בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: and has not raised his eyes to the fetishes of the House of Israel
target: inner orientation of desire and trust toward idols
ground: eyes represent attention and desire
direction of gaze symbolizes where trust is placed
looking up can signify reverence or appeal
posture: rejects even the desire that looks toward idols
instances.explanation: As in earlier verses, raising the eyes toward idols is an idiomatic, metaphorical way to speak of orienting one’s heart and trust toward them.

deliberation: The acts listed (not wronging, not seizing pledge, giving bread, clothing the naked) can be taken literally as social deeds. There is no clearly crafted figurative idiom beyond normal concrete description.
Identified two recurring idioms: withdrawing the hand from the poor, and walking in God's statutes. Both use bodily-motion imagery for moral/economic conduct.

instances.english_text: he has refrained from oppressing the poor (lit. he has withdrawn his hand from the poor)
target: ceasing exploitative treatment of the poor
vehicle: withdrawing the hand away from someone
ground: the hand stands for active power and exploitation
pulling back pictures ending such actions
physical non-contact symbolizes non-oppression
posture: moral exhortation by vivid bodily image
instances.explanation: Here the hand is metonymic for powerful, oppressive action; withdrawing it is a metaphorical idiom for no longer exploiting the poor.

instances.english_text: he has followed My laws (lit. walked in My statutes)
ground: life is like a journey
commands mark out a road to follow
faithfulness is steady step-by-step progress
posture: approves steady devotion to God's way
casts lawkeeping as a guided path
instances.explanation: As in verse 9, obedience is represented as walking inside God’s statutes as though traveling along a marked-out path.

deliberation: The father’s actions (defrauding, robbing) are literal. "He died in his iniquity" is a typical way of connecting death and sin, but functions as a causal/legal statement more than a developed metaphor.
The question "why has not the son borne the iniquity of the father" preserves the idiom of 'bearing iniquity', a metaphoric way of speaking of carrying guilt like a burden.

instances.english_text: Why has not the son shared the burden of his father’s guilt (lit. borne the iniquity of the father)?
ground: guilt is like a load that can be carried or not
to 'bear' it is to endure its consequences
transfer of burden pictures transfer of liability
posture: challenges an assumed pattern of shared liability
instances.explanation: The idiom pictures iniquity as a burden that can be borne; to 'bear iniquity' is to carry its guilt and penalty.

deliberation: Contains several stock metaphors: 'the soul that sins', bearing iniquity, and righteousness/wickedness being 'upon' someone. All frame moral realities in physical/bodily terms.

instances.english_text: Only the person (lit. the soul) who sins shall die
target: the individual human being who sins
ground: the 'soul' represents the whole living self
life as what is at stake in sin
identity located in the life-principle
posture: clarifies that death attaches to the acting person
instances.explanation: As in verse 4, 'nephesh' functions as a synecdoche for the entire person: the 'soul that sins' means the person who sins.

instances.hebrew_text: בֵּן לֹא־יִשָּׂא בַּעֲוֺן הָאָב וְאָב לֹא יִשָּׂא בַּעֲוֺן הַבֵּן
instances.english_text: A child shall not share the burden of a parent’s guilt, nor shall a parent share the burden of a child’s guilt (lit. shall not bear the iniquity)
target: legal and moral liability for another’s sin
experience of punishment for others' deeds
vehicle: bearing iniquity as a physical burden
ground: guilt conceived as a weight that can be placed on or removed from someone
to bear is to endure or suffer consequences
non-transfer of burden mirrors non-transfer of liability
posture: denies the transferability of guilt-burdens between generations
instances.explanation: The idiom again pictures iniquity as something carried; this verse explicitly denies that such a 'load' of guilt is borne across generational lines.

instances.hebrew_text: צִדְקַת הַצַּדִּיק עָלָיו תִּהְיֶה וְרִשְׁעַת הָרָשָׁע עָלָיו תִּהְיֶה
instances.english_text: the righteousness of the righteous shall be upon them alone, and the wickedness of the wicked shall be upon them alone
target: moral status and its consequences belonging to each person
vehicle: something resting on or covering a person
ground: what is 'upon' someone is what characterizes and affects them
moral qualities cling to the individual
covering/burden suggests inalienable association
posture: insists that each person 'wears' their own moral status
rejects the idea that another bears it instead
instances.explanation: Righteousness and wickedness are conceptualized as things that rest upon a person like a covering or burden, emphasizing personal ownership of moral status.

deliberation: Key figurative element is the 'turning back' from sins, a directional verb used metaphorically for repentance. 'Live' here can include covenant flourishing but in context is primarily literal life.

instances.hebrew_text: הָרָשָׁע כִּי יָשׁוּב מִכׇּל־חַטֹּאתָיו אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂה
instances.english_text: if someone wicked repents (lit. turns back) from all the sins that were committed
target: moral and spiritual change of direction
ground: life conceptualized as a path one walks
sin as a wrong way traveled
repentance as reversing one's course
posture: presents repentance as accessible and decisive
encourages turning as pathway to life
offers hope of reversal of destiny
instances.explanation: The verb 'turn back' (שׁוּב) is used metaphorically for repentance, picturing moral change as reversing one’s direction on a life path defined by one’s sins.

deliberation: Examined memory language. "Transgressions shall not be remembered" uses cognitive imagery for divine judicial treatment—God not 'remembering' means not bringing to account.

instances.hebrew_text: כׇּל־פְּשָׁעָיו אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂה לֹא יִזָּכְרוּ לוֹ
instances.english_text: None of the transgressions they committed shall be remembered against them
target: God’s judicial regard for past sins
ground: to 'remember' is to take into account or act upon
to 'forget' (not remember) is to disregard in action
record keeping parallels memory
posture: portrays divine mercy as a kind of intentional forgetting
assures repentant people their guilt record is cancelled
instances.explanation: The verse uses the metaphor/idiom of memory for divine judicial action: God’s not 'remembering' sins means He no longer counts them against the person.

deliberation: Looked for personification or metaphor. The key phrase "turn back from their ways" uses derekh ('way') as a life-course metaphor and 'turn back' for repentance.

instances.english_text: when they turn back from their ways and live
ground: life presented as a road one walks
pattern of conduct as 'ways'
repentance as retracing steps off a wrong path
posture: expresses God’s preference for repentance over death
frames repentance as accessible path to life
instances.explanation: The combination of 'ways' and 'turning back' uses the path metaphor for life and depicts repentance as changing the route one travels.

deliberation: Identified (1) 'turning from righteousness' as the same turning/path metaphor and (2) the non-remembrance of earlier righteous deeds using the memory-judgment metaphor as in verse 22.

instances.english_text: if someone righteous turns away from righteousness
vehicle: turning away from a position or path
ground: righteousness pictured as a path or standing one can turn from
direction of travel symbolizes moral choice
movement imagery expresses change
posture: warns that prior righteousness does not guarantee future safety
underscores the seriousness of moral reversal
instances.explanation: The righteous person is said to 'turn from' righteousness, using physical turning to represent abandoning a righteous way of life.

instances.english_text: None of the righteous deeds that they did shall be remembered
target: God’s judicial regard for prior righteous acts
ground: what is 'remembered' influences present treatment
forgetting erases practical effect
juridical record parallel to memory
posture: stresses that present sin can cancel the benefit of past righteousness
instances.explanation: The same memory metaphor as in verse 22 is applied to righteousness: God’s not 'remembering' it means it is not credited in the face of subsequent treachery.

deliberation: Searched for figurative terms. The repeated phrase "the way of the Lord / your ways" uses 'way' (derekh) metaphorically for conduct or policy, and 'House of Israel' is a metonymy for the people.

instances.english_text: the Sovereign’s way ... your ways
target: God’s manner of judging, Israel’s manner of living
ground: behavior and policy are like a path to follow
consistency/direction of action mirrors a road’s course
one can evaluate a 'way' as straight or twisted
posture: defends the rightness of God’s 'way' and indicts Israel’s
rhetorical contrast between divine and human paths
instances.explanation: The term 'way' metaphorically represents habitual conduct or policy, contrasting God’s just 'way' with Israel’s unjust 'ways.'

instances.english_text: House of Israel
ground: a 'house' can stand for the family inhabiting it
collective identity expressed as one household
spatial unit representing social unit
posture: addresses the whole people as a single family unit
instances.explanation: The phrase 'House of Israel' is a metonymy where 'house' stands for the entire people descended from Israel.

deliberation: Parallels verse 24, reiterating the 'turning from righteousness' motif. The dying 'for' the wrong is causal, not especially figurative beyond legal usage.

instances.english_text: When someone righteous turns away from righteousness and does wrong
target: abandoning a righteous pattern of life
vehicle: turning away from a path or position
ground: righteousness conceptualized as a path one walks
leaving that path is like turning aside
movement imagery conveys change and betrayal
posture: emphasizes accountability for present conduct over past record
warns against presumption based on former righteousness
instances.explanation: The physical act of 'turning' is used metaphorically for forsaking a righteous way of life and engaging in injustice.

deliberation: Identified two expressions: (1) turning back from wickedness (path metaphor) and (2) 'he will make his life live' as an idiom portraying a person as actively preserving their own life.

instances.english_text: if someone wicked turns back from the wickedness that is practiced
target: repentance from a sinful way of life
vehicle: turning back from a path one was on
ground: evil conduct conceptualized as a road traveled
repentance as reversing course
direction of motion mirrors moral orientation
posture: encourages the possibility of radical change
ties such turning to preservation of life
instances.explanation: The wickedness is treated as a route from which the person can 'turn back', using the path metaphor for moral conduct and repentance.

instances.english_text: he shall save his life (lit. he will make his soul live)
ground: life treated as something one can 'cause to live' through choices
agency in securing or forfeiting life
soul as the seat of life
posture: stresses human responsibility in choosing life by repentance
gives hopeful agency to the wicked person
instances.explanation: The idiom portrays the penitent as actively 'making his soul live', using causative life-language metaphorically for conserving one’s own life by changing conduct.

deliberation: Again features 'turning back from all his transgressions', the now-familiar path/turning metaphor for repentance. 'He shall live, not die' is a stark literal outcome pairing.

instances.english_text: because they took heed and turned back from all the transgressions that they committed
vehicle: turning back from something one was moving toward
ground: sins conceptualized as a direction or route one follows
to repent is to reverse course away from them
movement image conveys decisiveness and thoroughness
posture: assures that genuine turning brings life
presents repentance as a clear break with former transgressions
instances.explanation: The verb 'turn back' is again metaphorical for repentance, with the plural 'transgressions' forming the wrongward course one abandons.

deliberation: Repeats the 'way of the Lord / your ways' contrast and the metonymic 'House of Israel' address, as in verse 25.

instances.english_text: The Sovereign’s way ... your ways
target: God’s mode of judgment, Israel’s mode of living
ground: conduct and policy are like a route followed
consistency of behavior corresponds to a path’s direction
paths can be evaluated as right or wrong, straight or crooked
instances.explanation: As before, 'way' (derekh) is a metaphor for habitual conduct or policy, and the verse contrasts God’s 'way' with Israel’s 'ways.'

instances.english_text: House of Israel
ground: 'house' often stands for the family within it
collective can be pictured as one household
spatial unit representing social whole
posture: addresses Israel as a unified family
highlights corporate responsibility for views of God’s way
instances.explanation: Again 'House of Israel' is a metonymy where the term 'house' represents the entire people descended from Israel.

deliberation: Found three figurative elements: judging 'according to your ways' (path metaphor), 'House of Israel' as metonymy, and 'stumbling block of iniquity' where sin is pictured as an obstacle that trips a person.

instances.english_text: I will judge each one of you according to your own ways
ground: behavior is like a path traced over time
one can be judged based on the course taken
paths encapsulate direction and destination
posture: presents judgment as fair evaluation of one’s chosen route
instances.explanation: Each person’s 'ways' are metaphorical paths representing their pattern of conduct, which God will use as the basis of judgment.

instances.english_text: House of Israel
ground: a 'house' can denote the family inhabiting it
political or ethnic group conceived as one household
built structure representing a lineage
instances.explanation: Once more, 'House of Israel' is a metonymy in which the term 'house' stands for the whole people descended from Israel.

instances.english_text: let them not be a stumbling block of guilt for you
target: the effect of sins on those who commit them
vehicle: a stumbling block (obstacle) that trips a walker
stone or object in a path
ground: sin causes one to fall/come to ruin like a stone causes a person to trip
obstacles impede progress along a way
guilt can bring one down
posture: urges removal of sin to avoid self-harm
pastoral admonition framed in path imagery
instances.explanation: Iniquity is pictured as a 'stumbling block', an obstacle in one’s path that causes a damaging fall, using road imagery for the destructive effects of sin.

deliberation: Contains several strong metaphors: 'cast away' transgressions (sins as objects thrown off), 'new heart' and 'new spirit' (inner life conceptualized as heart/spirit that can be renewed), and 'House of Israel' metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: הַשְׁלִיכוּ מֵעֲלֵיכֶם אֶת־כׇּל־פִּשְׁעֵיכֶם אֲשֶׁר פְּשַׁעְתֶּם בָּם
instances.english_text: Cast away all the transgressions by which you have offended
vehicle: removing a burden or object from upon oneself
ground: sins are like unwanted burdens or objects clinging to a person
repentance is like throwing them off
distance from an object symbolizes freedom from its influence
posture: urges decisive and active renunciation of sin
frames sin as something externalizable and discardable
pastoral exhortation to radical break with past
instances.explanation: Transgressions are metaphorically treated as objects lying upon the people that they can and must 'cast away' from themselves.

instances.english_text: get yourselves a new heart
ground: the heart is conceived as the seat of thought, will and desire
a 'new' heart signifies a transformed inner orientation
inner renewal likened to organ replacement
posture: calls for radical internal transformation, not just external reform
emphasizes responsibility to seek such renewal
instances.explanation: The 'heart' is a standard biblical metaphor for the inner person (mind, will, desires); a 'new heart' signifies a fundamentally renewed inner life.

instances.english_text: and a new spirit
ground: spirit conceptualized as the breath or wind animating a person
a 'new' spirit suggests a fresh, different inner drive
inner attitude likened to an animating wind
posture: underscores need for fresh inner empowerment and attitude
balances 'heart' as will with 'spirit' as energy
instances.explanation: Here 'spirit' is metaphorical for the animating inner principle of a person; a 'new spirit' means a new, God-oriented disposition.

instances.english_text: House of Israel
ground: a 'house' can stand for the family or dynasty it houses
one term represents the whole social group
spatial image stands for collective identity
posture: again addresses Israel as one family-unit under God
instances.explanation: As elsewhere, 'House of Israel' uses 'house' as a metonym for the entire people descended from Israel.

deliberation: Theologically rich but figuratively focused phrase is the final imperative 'turn and live', using the standard turning/path metaphor for repentance as the route to life.

instances.english_text: Repent, therefore, and live! (lit. Turn back and live!)
target: repentant change of life leading to preservation of life
ground: life is like a journey on a path
turning back from the wrong road leads to safety/life
repentance as directional change has life-or-death consequences
posture: expresses God’s desire for life rather than death
implores the audience to choose life by changing course
instances.explanation: The imperative 'turn back' (repent) uses the path-turning metaphor to urge a decisive change of direction that results in continuing to live.
